149955229.review:
Once again, wishing Steam offered a neutral rating.

The premise, gameplaywise, is actually superb. Superfluously it seems like a VN where you just need to click to coast from dialogue option to dialogue option and just test each conversation choice until you get the right combo to get to the right ending.

Turns out it's a little more complex than that; there are icons on some of the screens that can be clicked to look at new stuff that gives new information, offering a little flavor text - and, more importantly, unlocking new dialogue that leads to a more optimistic route. 

Still, this discovery- and getting any use out of it- was limited for me to the phone screen, where you can click the Twitter icon - and may we please just praise that these absolute madlads had the guts to actually show *Twitter*, in their for-profit game, no parody name or icon or anything!? Major points, Akaba! We need more stones like this in public media publishers - to see the leading lady's profile to see a bit of her personality and unlock a movie option that she'll actually get excited about (all the rest, she's apathetic to).

Once it got to what seems like the next scene where this is hinted to be possible - a split screen of the boy and the woman in their respective rooms - you can make some objects increase in size slightly by hovering over them, but clicking on them doesn't do anything; you just have to advance through the dialgoue the obvious way until they get to an anticlimactic "I gotta go", which leads you down the disfunctional ending.

I did accidentally get them to start making content-specific speech bubbles about their things before that, once, but I haven't been able to replicate it - and the truth is, this sleepy little awkward "love" story doesn't really make me care enough to bother troubleshooting it, not when the option to refund and get some money back hovers overhead.

___

This game is meant for people who really, *really* like awkward and disturbing romance sims, and for people who have the spare time -and interest - in a "guess-and-check" style for playing multiple-ending games. For such folk, maybe there's something here; that "Overwhelmingly positive" rating obviously comes from somewhere.

But for folks who prefer at least some clues to piece together to get to the right answer, make the right timing, and who frankly want an experience they can squeeze between sessions of working on their college essays, I definitely can't recommend this in good conscience. 

___

Still, I for one am glad to see some Chinese developers actually getting a chance to spread their wings openly and to a warm welcome in a Western Market. I definitely encourage Akaba Studio to continue; I'm ready for some healing between Chinese and American cultures wherever it can happen, even if it has to be through something so niche and silly as indie games.

149941581.review:
[h1]A Personal Journey with LoveChoice[/h1]
LoveChoice, a game that might resonate differently with each player, holds a special place in my heart, especially for those who have had recent emotional experiences. While it may not have a universal appeal, I highly recommend giving it a chance.


[h1]Why LoveChoice Impressed Me[/h1]
This game stands out with its clever use of game design elements, paired with straightforward storytelling that’s both engaging and thought-provoking. The developers have skillfully balanced simplicity with depth, creating an experience that’s subtly impactful. The second story, in particular, was a highlight for me. It weaves its narrative in a manner that’s both intuitive and immersive, making every moment in the game feel significant and emotionally charged, and terribly realistic..


I must also commend the developers for bringing their GameJam idea to life. Additionally, discovering that this game was released on my birthday added a personal layer of joy to my experience :)


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
LoveChoice transcends the boundaries of a mere game, evolving into an emotional journey that intertwines complexity and simplicity. Its masterful portrayal of the complexities of relationships strikes a chord. The game delves deep (enough) into the intricacies of human connections, exploring how choices and consequences weave the tapestry of our interactions. This exploration is both thought-provoking and poignant, challenging players to reflect on the nature of relationships and the delicate balance of effort and acceptance.
Through its interactive storytelling, LoveChoice highlights that not all fractures in relationships can be mended, and some truths are harder to face than others. This realization, though bittersweet, is a powerful takeaway from the game. It may not resonate with everyone, but for those it touches, it does well.

[b]P.S.[/b] I was expecting her to say "Shin demo ii wa" ^^, but still lovely reference to Natsume Sōseki.

LoveChoice"is a game centered around AVG selection gameplay. There are three types of love in this game, one of which is to bravely take the first step; There is a kind of love called letting go, which is no longer about; There is a kind of love called taking responsibility and running in both directions. Every choice you make is like a butterfly flapping its wings, which may lead to a happy ending or a bad ending. But what I want to say is that in real life, every decision you make cannot be made from scratch. From the moment you finish playing the game and turn off the computer, your game has already started. Finally, I wish all lovers a happy ending! 
《拣爱》是一款以AVG选择玩法为核心的游戏。这个游戏共有三种爱，有一种爱就是勇敢迈出第一步；有一种爱叫做放手，不再关乎；有一种爱叫做各自负责，双向奔赴。你的每一次选择都是蝴蝶扇动翅膀，可能最后是个美好的结局，可能后面是一个坏结局。但我想说的是人生没有存档，且行且珍惜，从玩完游戏关闭电脑的那一刻，属于你的游戏就已经开始了，最后祝大家有情人终成眷属！

146501993.review:
Nice Stories, but unfair game design.

pro:
+ Worth the full price. And yes, it does not cost much.
+ The music and graphics are sweet and touching.
+ Large language support.
+ Short game focused on the core-experience.
+ Mini-games discribe real-life situations surprisingly well.
+ The game has nice lessons within the stories, that can be eye-opening. You need to think a bit, what could be the solution to a problem - BUT...

con:
- ...the game does not tell you, that there is a problem anyway. It does not tell your options of acting. You have to lose every story, to know what is coming and to grind to success in the repeat of the game. That breaks the hole concept of a serious relationship-simulation for me and makes it feel like a soulslike - "dying foreward".
Idea: A tutorial-story would be nice, that shows you, what the game expects as kind of game-controlls, for example: drawing your character from point a to b, very fast click-picking, searching pictures, concentration tests, NOT-clicking is same important as choosing correctly, profiling/stalking your mate, unexpected change of character, etc.

- Not shown timer for actions. Often you have 5-10 seconds to act, without knowing.
- Trying to find the solutions is tiring/exhausting.
- Female rolemodel seem a bit very passive and quiet. Could be a character-trait, but is also a bit outdated. In an adult realtionship you learn to express your expectations on both sides - equally. In the game the male person is realy the main acting charakter, that needs to take care for almost everything. -> The balance the game itselfs teaches is not embodied through the game itself. The line between balance and toxic-caretaking gets thin in this game.

Conclusion:
All in all a  sweet serious game, that need to be more fair in player-game communication. 
...it should enact/perform its own lessons...better.

144757538.review:
Love Choice has 3 mini stories. All of them have multiple endings. It's not obvious what to do at first. My first few tries I got the bad endings. However, taking the time to focus on the text and experimenting a bit with clicking around rather than just choosing from the text box options, I quickly figured out what I was doing wrong, and managed to get better endings. 

Even with experimentation though, it is hard to figure out by yourself how to get to certain story-lines. If you care about getting a 100% in achievements or getting all the in-game album photos, you might have to look some stuff up.

While it's not the most complex game about love, it sure is an emotional and (bitter)sweet one. I definitely recommend giving it a go.

IRRELEVANT RANT AHEAD: Like others have said, this game made me realize my own shortcomings. It gave me a new perspective on my own relationship (and a really good anniversary gift idea for when me and my boyfriend will finally move in :). It also made me really miss him, ldr really sucks. I know story 2, the distance story, aims to portray the harsh fact that sometimes things just don't work out. Played this at 2 am, and am now crying at 5 am having completed the game 100%. The intention from the developers shows wonderfully in teaching you the lessons that come from relationship issues and knowing the difference between what you can and cannot control in them.
All stories teach different things and all of them have their own individual feeling and charm. They may not be equally enjoyable to everyone, but I sure did love the way the bittersweet take on love permeates throughout this game. 

9/10, would play again after a breakup or after starting a relationship

143695563.review:
Yeah I'd recommend this game since it's extremely cheap and pretty well-made. 

There are three modes that you can play that revolve around love: First Love, Long Distance, and Detective.

First Love is your basic romance in which you ask out your crush and become her boyfriend. Depending on your choices and actions, the relation can either flop or continue on.

Long Distance is similar to First Love except you are faced with trying to maintain a long-distance relationship. Once again, your choices and actions affect the outcome of this relationship.

Finally, we have Detective which is about a wife trying to find out what her husband has been doing behind her back (it's not what you think). This mode is unique in that it's basically a mini point-and-click puzzle game.

Anyway the game plays like a visual novel except for the fact that there are moments in the game where you really need to think outside of the box. For instance, you'd need to drag the boyfriend to the girlfriend in a moment. Another one is simply not pressing the dialogue button while the couple are trash-talking each other. Hence it's extremely important to use a guide to play this game because some of the endings are locked behind stuff that you wouldn't know to do at first glance.

142004399.review: Pretty nuanced take on relationships and an interesting story. I genuinely think the first blind play-through is very eye opening for letting people learn on how to be a good partner. I.e. you have to be proactive to do the things that are right in the framework of a relationship. Don't fixate on making a good impression in order to be able to date someone, talk about your genuine interests and ask them about theirs. Don't sit down and play your phone when your s/o is talking about their problems, and sit next to them and be shoulder they can lean on. It's a good game and I find the morals they try to teach to be quite logical and mature.

141974654.review:
It's one of those games that deserves a "MAYBE". 

If you're expecting a game where your choices influence the outcome of these relationships. This isn't really it, only one of the three stories actually has a choice. And as you'd expect, these morals and attitudes mirror the Asian Dating culture and some things might not make much sense to westerners.

The game is more like "I wanna be the guy" x visual novel. You're supposed to find hidden options instead of choosing the seemingly 2-4 limited obvious choices. Such as, instead of choosing any dialogue option, you're supposed to click on something in the picture itself or wait for the time to run out. Once you figure out that's the point of the game, it becomes straight forward since 90% of the right answers are these hidden visual choices. (I suppose the game is trying to say actions are better than words.)

Cute story, nice music. The second story turned up the "feels-metre", but I personally related to the last story and it floored me. So for that, I'll you deserve a like. Can't be too angry with a game that costs a 1$.

139435634.review:
Not saying 'not recommended' cus it's cute also lovely and does not deserve the thumbs down. 
        H  o  w  e  v  e  r . . . 

Game lookin' cute, BUT no hints are given of how you are supposed to be playing, what you should look for. (I get it "as in relationship" but i highly doubt that hidden objects would help me to get a good relationship, also if i've been stalking my guy he'd probably block me straight away kekw) Actually 100% relatable how no communication and forcing each other to do stuff will ruin everything. Since you are probably going to be as clueless as i was when i started in good faith, I can almost guarantee you're going to get the 'bad ' ending for the first try, but that's ok you can always start again.

Tagged with "Dating sim." - you barely have a few options to choose from upon dialogues, or what to do, how to approach them, yet it barely effects the ending cus there 3 of it, (good- neutral - 'bad') it's only up to you, how you can pick on the 'hidden' details and make changes in the ending. 

No chemistry or whatsoever between the characters, like, at all. They're just there, '"dev made them to be together" and I didnt feel good or bad if they got together or not.. Did not feel RPG at all, just to pick one dialog out of the 3 does not make it a rpg. (IMO) cus it does not affect that obviously. Leaving me with the question: If my approaching was so bad how did we end up dating anyway...? 
[spoiler] (How is that a bad approach to just introduce yourself???!!) [/spoiler]

'Recommended cause i have played Our Life / Undertale' (????): I've been absolutely tricked... Addicted to both, yet i don't think this one should be among them.

So little differences are there, dialogues, playthrous are also the same each time. Mini games are ..eh. 

I think there should be more opportunity to actually learn about our "partners" than if you notice this or that on the walls you gonna get the girl..



Good thing you can actually get a refund after finishing the game but honetly, i do not feel this fair towards the devs. Music is also sweet, and so are the drawings. 
I'm not saying it's so bad you shouldn't even give it a chance (for me) there are definitely better dating sims, also the feedbacks are absolutely positive for a reason, and it's not expensive at all either.

"I will let you go."

"Go for it. I know that's your dream."

Sometimes, the hardest decision to make is the right one. I understand that, but I couldn't resist the urge to try to make it work. I despise how my selfishness is impacting our futures, but I can't shake the vision of a world where everything falls into place.

Not only for this game, but I hope all of you in a similar situation can carefully and thoroughly consider your choices. Don't act impulsively, thinking that you're just missing out on one person when, in reality, you're missing out on an entire lifetime. Don't think that you will forget her; one will never forget someone they genuinely love.

137068178.review:
I love what this game has to say about love!!! (ironic, isn't it?)

The name and the end credit song imply very well that, whenever you can, you must make a LoveChoice. And it is interesting that, mirroring life, the choices that are made through love are not the obvious one. This game plays with our gaming muscle memory in the sense that we are trained to interact the way that the game display prompts us very explicitly. And we've been playing games and pressing X when the HUD says so (even without reflection sometimes) for years. So it comes as a shock how hard we fail at building relationships while doing what we have been doing without effort or a second thought for years. But it would only make sense narratively that when we automatize our relationships, loving as one would push a button (without care, attention and reflection), they don't move forward. And that is precisely what the game invoked on me!

That's where this game's brilliance lies. The LoveChoice is not an obvious action, but it is attention to detail. Reading the room, understanding when to remain quiet, when to let go, when to not push the boundaries of trust. It invites us to stop engaging with the narrative as gamers and start engaging as caring people. And in that way, it's a puzzle game instead of a visual novel. Much like the way meeting new people is puzzling, and there is often a third choice not prompted in the dialogue options. 

 It was really sweet, and i definitely recommend and will be keeping an eye on the Devs bc i loved their work (i suppose that's the LoveChoice I'm making now then).

137034190.review: Maybe as someone who's been in an 8+ year relationship, dealing with the complexities of human emotion and nuanced communication, I found this game a little too... simplistic? How am I supposed to get to know a character when I only have two (sometimes one) choice for how to respond or approach a situation? Is there a way to ASK this virtual character what kind of movies she likes? Or should I assume that because she's a girl, she'll like romantic comedies? Which I guess is my other big problem with this game. I'm sorry, I know it's only $2, but it's extraordinarily heteronormative. Blue and pink text to tell who's talking? C'mon... I guess I'm not the target audience.

136830304.review:
When I saw this game on a Steam sale, I was interested. Added it to my wishlist but forgot about it.
Later I ended up buying it not on sale, and even without the sale the game is a bargain. For the story and feelings it delivers, I think it is severly underpriced.

Although the came is very simply, it is made of puzzles, and has a lot of diverse and interesting mechanics. One of the funnier ones was the mouse running away. Some of the mechanics I didn't understand right away, but it's ok.

I have to say that every single one of these stories has made me cry and, as I sit here writing this review, my eyes are still watery. The narratives are straightforward but full of lessons and you cna't help but empathize with their feelings, pains and journeys.

The first and third story have possible [spoiler]happy endings[/spoiler]. The second story [spoiler]could be argued that it has a possible happy ending, where both work hard and achieve their dreams, but it is not possible to end happy together in any of the paths. Which is ok, because life isn't always fair and you don't get everything you want.[/spoiler]

I think the second story was the one that hit me the hardest, being in a similar situation.

But even if you are not in a relationship, the narratives were crafted with a lot of love and care, and you will find yourself crying on your keyboard.

This game is 5/5 and I can't stress enough that even in doubt, you should buy it. It's an amazing experience that you won't regret.

135123824.review:
10/10 I wept (twice).

LoveChoice is a really thoughtfully crafted game. For $1.50 you get 3 very sweet short stories, each with their own different lessons and takeaways (all of which are extremely relevant in real life). For me personally, the first story's takeaways are [spoiler] emotional awareness/empathy, listening, effort, reading the room, and not ever growing complacent. Also, the game reveals that the creator used that game to propose to her. Very emo moment, I was very teary. [/spoiler] The second story's takeaways are [spoiler] being considerate, that sometimes effort alone isn't enough, sometimes things are about timing, and sometimes having a relationship isn't necessarily the ultimate priority... and that's okay. [/spoiler] The third story's takeaways are [spoiler] trust, and once again, not ever growing complacent. [/spoiler] Of course, though, I think there are plenty of different things to take away for each individual. I recommend going in blind and trying to unlock all the achievements to get the different endings. The hints that are scattered within the text about what could have been different are enough as long as you actually think about them.

The best ending for the 3rd story hits really hard if you're in a relationship. Before the credits roll, [spoiler] it gives you the chance to enter your own names, and the game wishes you well in your own relationship. [/spoiler] It's very tastefully sweet and emotional. I cried a lot.

I think everyone has something they can learn and reflect on from this game. It's also a dollar so like... why not.

I never been in a relationship, so I had no idea about the norm/standard when it comes to dating. In my first playthrough, I had a bad ending, so I decided to repeat the game and made other choices to see different outcomes. The more I played, the more I realized that there weren't any good choices for certain scenarios as I always ended up with a bad ending. I then proceed to wonder that maybe there can be another choice that best fits the scenario. As a result, I was playing around with my mouse then discovered that I can actually interact with the images. 

The lessons that I could learn from this game are that: 
- Love is simple and it just us that makes it complicated. 
- Trust and constant communication is a must have in a relationship.   
- True Love and Friendship will last no matter the distance.
- There is no standard when it comes to love, as it may vary from one person to another.
- If you truly love someone, you shouldn't expect anything in return and just wish the best for them even it means no longer being part of their life. You may not end up with them but at least you had change them for the better.

I was expecting a short visual novel type of gameplay but this game exceeded my expectation. Thank you very much developers for the awesome game!

134244690.review:
[h1]A game about love and relationships[/h1]

[b]Make sure to play it blind, without any guides. At least your first attempt, and see the result.[/b]

It is easy to get into relationship. But can you maintain it forever? Do not get discouraged if you fail on your first attempt to live happily together. And do not look for easy guides, just replay the game and look carefully at all of the solutions. Best ones, are not visible to the player :) Just think before you click.
LoveChoice will help you to understand some principles and the fact that every decision has consequences. Like in real life scenario.

Hard to say much more about this game - just act like you would in real life and see what happens. 
Graphic is simple but beautiful, music is calming and suits the game well. There's plethora of languages to choose from.

[b]It's easily a 10/10, well crafted indie game. Will force you to think - and if you are in relationship (even if you're married), about your own behaviour and impact on the other half. A short and simple title with very powerful message. 
Try to get all of the endings, you will shed a tear or two.

132688229.review:
During the Lunar New Year sale, this game was under $1 and had overwhelmingly positive reviews, so I just mindlessly picked it up while buying a couple other games. After playing it over the course of 3 streams, this short game has proven itself as an innovative, insightful, and profound look into love an relationships. I'm going to put up front that if you like romance, are in a relationship, or are looking to be in a relationship, you will probably like this game, and should just buy / play it now to avoid any possible minor spoilers.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

LoveChoice is split into 3 subgames,"Love.Game", "Love.Distance", and "Love.Detective" each with their own self contained story. While, at first, LoveChoice seems to play like a typical visual novel, you come to find that having a successful relationship requires much more than trying to find the right reply from a list of canned responses. Each subgame is also unique in how it uses the gameplay to tell it's story. "Love.Game" plays more like a typical visual novel, "Love.Distance" plays like  a hidden object / spot the difference game, and "Love.Detective" plays like an escape room. But the thing that makes this game special is that if you coast along playing the game as you expect, you're not going to get the best endings. It's when you go above and beyond, breaking through the established norms of the genre, do you become a better lover, and get the good endings.

[b]Art[/b]

The art is cute and nicely stylized, and the cgs make for wonderful desktop backgrounds which can be downloaded through the game itself. The music is nice but is never very remarkable outside of the song played during the credits

[b]Story[/b]

Each of the 3 stories feel extremely real, to the point where I legitimately thought some of them were retellings / expansions on events that happened in real life. Akaba Studio also manages to cover a wide range of emotions through it's storytelling, showing you the exciting beginnings of a relationship, the problems that arise, the complacency that can form. "Love.Distance" made me tear up by showcasing the bitter reality of sometimes needing to let go of the person you love the most. And "Love.Detective" made me tear up by showing one of the most romantic anniversary gifts I've seen.

[b]Overall[/b]

In it's 2 hr runtime LoveChoice made me smile, tear up, and reflect upon my own relationship. I found it's subversion of visual novel mechanics to be refreshing and also meaningful to the themes the game presents. I believe LoveChoice presents love in a way only that can only be experinced through the medium of video games.

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

LoveChoice is a beautiful look into relationships and can be enjoyed by couples, fans of romance, and just about anyone.

On one hand, the game is so cheap and short that strict scrutiny doesn't feel justified.

 On the other, I don't understand how anyone can find anything profound in this game as there are no hard choices revolving around the relationships at all - you just need to think outside the box of visual novels and don't jump at the first given option(s).

Some might say it has positive messages about love and relationships but because of how brief the game is, the subject isn't treated with the level of nuance it needs and thus, those messages reveal how hollow they are if you think just a minute about it. It truly felt like a Dhar Mann video turned into a video game.

It is by no means something unworthy of the money but that's not because it's great but it is just cheap af. I think the top comments and the overall 'Overwhelmingly Positive' verdict unjustly hype the game up, so I'm going with a negative.

131874558.review:
I was never invested in playing novel games such as this. But I was kind of feeling down from personal setbacks and college, and so I thought maybe I could give it a try. BOY, I was not disappointed. I cried instead. Cried of tears, pain, joy, and love.

I love the art style, the music, the story on each part... literally everything. It gave me a good cry and somehow this game resonated with me for reasons:

1. Pet in the game was a cat, and I myself is a cat lover! PLEASE GIVE BLACKY A HEADPAT AND SAY HI TO HIM/HER FOR ME! <3

2. Love will always touch you in mysterious ways, such as playing this game. Each part (Game, Distance, Detective) was unique, and all of them gave me manly cries.

3. I do have a girlfriend and it made me feel so soft. This game just makes me appreciate her existence in my life and miss her so much every hour, every day. Call it cheesy, but that's what this game made me feel all throughout the stories. It made me feel loved, and it pushes me to thrive as a person and as a partner, and strive to the good of our relationship.

131476675.review:
LoveChoice拣爱 is a visual novel-esque game with 3 short stories jumbled into a game, from my initial point of view yeah,  it's cute overall game at first glance, boy was I in for a ride.

I was so baffled when at the start I got the bad ending straightaway, but as I kept on replaying Love · Game on my 2nd and 3rd play through it struck me.

[i]Sometimes it's not just words you need, your actions matter. [/i]

Simple really but it really struck a cord in me, sometimes giving generic replies and answers isn't always the case. You have to show it that you mean it. It surprised me when I could not just gave a reply back to the person, but actually interact with the moving background. It was so cute how it broke the 4th wall by making you not just give a reply in the text box but actually interacting with the environment making you an observant person.

As with how things goes too there's a moment in the Love · Game, [spoiler]where you are arguing with your significant other you would assume and click on the dialogue insinuating you to bite back and get even more frustrated but really the correct thing was to let it go and cool off.[/spoiler] Just by not interacting back at all you really are doing the right thing.

Generally when it comes to visual novel-type games there really isn't much to say, you read, you click, you save rinse and repeat, but the twist in this visual novel is that you can either continue with the given prompts or interact with said background. Minor thing but it can puts things into perspective with you missing cues or whether or not you're supposed to ignore it.

For the story, I've completed all 3 mini-love stories that are included in this visual novel. Below are my thoughts.

In Love · Game, I've loved every single aspect of it from the start to the end. How it was handled, how the characters interact and of course the endings I've gotten. Good or bad, they're both important valuable lessons that were taught here and there.

In Love · Distance like it's in its name, distance can and will change a person. Without spoiling too much, time will inevitably change certain aspects of an relationship whether people agree or disagree. There are plenty of choices where you think you would've done or could've done but ultimately it is best if we go our own separate ways, to find what truly matters for yourself.

In Love · Detective, I already went in with a raised eyebrow assuming as what the previous titles meant for it's story, and you would've guessed it is... detective work alright. I didn't know what I had in store for me when I realized.... sometimes choosing not to know is the right choice, not saying to be ignorant of the choice you made but choosing to believe your person.

Music is quite subjective, so from what I've listened it's generally fits the theme of this game and mood. When you first met, when you're talking, when you're arguing, when you're being sentimental. The simplicity of the melody brings out the best in what's happening currently. So, yes I do love the music, thank you MIDIPanda.

All in all, I'm very happy how the game is and I'm suuuuper satisfied and gave me tons of fuzzy warmth feelings in the inside.

131324626.review:
This review contains: game play/art/plot

Love Actually -- Lessons for not only romantic relationships but it can be applied to any relationship (friendships)

When we think of an otome/visual novel -- we're usually given expectations of something linear. Something scripted in a way that either sets us up for a specific route in mind. Or something that's so wild beyond belief that it's easy for us to suspend our realities and play along in the fantasy world of the game. But that's just it, a game. But LoveChoice is more than just a game, it's... love actually. Love in a way that isn't always happy or isn't always perfect.

GAME PLAY:
I, like many others, played the first story and got broken up with. I didn't know why and I was thoroughly confused -- especially since the choices seem limited. It seems like you only have a few options, but after playing through it once I realized that the choices felt shallow. (minor spoiler) [spoiler] And in the end letter, the game tells you that to some extent [/spoiler]. I realized that there was something missing, something that didn't add up, and I realized that it's not at all as it seems. The first part has the most variances you can probably get and by testing out different ways to go about it, you'll be able to pick up on the rest of the game pretty easily -- but I will admit I was pretty challenged for a bit. I even succumbed to looking up the answers a few times. However, REMEMBER there's always another way (minor spoiler)[spoiler] until you get to the second story where I may be a liar[/spoiler].

ART:
Let's start with the art, it's simplistic but meaningful. It isn't something that's intensely decorated like Heart Fragment or maybe even Our Life, but it is very cute and simplistic until you start digging a little deeper. It's good though because for the amount of solving that you (as the player) must do, it helps prevent any unnecessary distraction. The music is also soft and sweet, sometimes even bitter. It fits well with the story you follow along with.

STORY/PLOT:
Now I'll talk about the stories - I'll try to be as vague as I can while providing solid content.

Story 1 [spoiler] this story is the one with the most variances in how you play. Everything matters, and the game will try to help you a bit by showing you small prompts but realize that not everything is as it seems. I failed a few times before I even realized that there is a puzzle element and an interactive element to the game -- something besides just clicking on an scripted answer. I didn't even realize that the game was a puzzle (clearly someone did not read any tags) until I played it the 3rd time. That being said [/spoiler] PLAY IT MORE THAN 1 TIME. Like many other users here, this story not only teaches or reminds us about what love can be but how to have a healthy form of it. 

That's the key isn't it? A healthy relationship with people? I'm sure everyone's heard of a toxic relationship or have been in one (friendships count just as much as romances!). It's hard to create and maintain if not everyone's on board. In fact, I'd argue that it's impossible to have a healthy relationship without everyone sacrificing a little bit of something. Even though the game play makes it seem obvious on what you should click on -- don't be afraid to think outside of the box. But play the game first however you feel is right, and let your results speak to you. Let them tell you exactly what went right or what went wrong. You don't have to have everything perfect and that's alright.

What relationship is ever picture perfect?

Story 2 As you can probably figure out, this story is about long distance. I''ll be completely transparent. I've never had a romantic partner drift away from me due to distance, but I've had loads of friends who have. Friends who I considered to be family at some point. It's hard trying to cling on to a friend who tries to cling on to you, but your lives are too dramatically different for you to be happy in that sort of friendship. I'm not saying that all friendships/relationships can't be happy, but I've found it to be very difficult if you've met the person and formed a relationship in real life and transitioning it to online. 

[Spoiler] The second story has the best bitter sweet plot. To some extent we know what will happen. We know the very real possibility of things not working out, but the optimist in us wants it to work out anyways. You'll feel the awkwardness, you'll feel the distance between the MC's (Grace and Stan in this story), and your heart will fracture just a bit because... No one wants to let go. I know I didn't want to let go, I know I never want to let someone so close to me go. You might feel different and that's totally okay, because you can let go. But I tried to keep it together until the end. [/Spoiler]

Remember what I said about -- there's always another option? This game might make me a liar but you get to decide at the end of this story. This story line was the first one to really make me think about my own trauma and my own life experiences. Why did I choose specific actions knowing it might not work out? Why did I stay optimistic throughout the game? These questions didn't necessarily pop up during the 1st story for me, but jumped out in this one. It might be because I've figured out how to play the game but it also might be because this plot hits closer to home for me.

The moral of this story is still carried from the last, what make a healthy relationship 'healthy?' Even though we might not want to do something [spoiler] I know for me it's a trauma response [/spoiler] sometimes it's better to bite the bullet and 'just do it' as Nike says. Because at the end of the day, we have to love and have compassion for ourselves too.

Story 3, again, triggers another trauma response (I'm trying not to use this term loosely but after going through some professional therapy -- trauma isn't defined as clearly as we may think so I think it's fitting in this context) from me even though I can masquerade it as curiosity. When we hear romance and detective -- we might hope for the game to be something like a mystery romance murder. But with the track record of the first two stories being so realistic, this one probably won't tangent too far away from that.

[Spoiler] This plot makes you a detective, a super slooth, and an international super spy (not really). You'll understand right away as the story kicks off pretty quickly and has a knack for making you suspicious. [/spoiler] Unlike the other two, this one is much more linear. Once you pick a poison, you have it until the bitter end. It's really engaging because unlike the other two you get to roam around your apartment you share with your husband. It seems innocent enough, curiosity and all, but realistically why would anyone snoop around? What are we trying to find? This plot, since it's so much more linear, brings out our curiosities but also relates back to that ever important theme of 'healthy relationships.'

CONCLUSION
All of these stories have their own special thing going about them, and while everyone will pick up different lessons that they want. It's undeniable that there is a massive emphasis on the question 'what makes a healthy relationship and what makes it toxic?' I think it's an important question to ask, because I certainly didn't know the difference for a while. In fact, I still probably have problems distinguishing between the two. I'm aware of my own problems to some degree, but I didn't realize that they were prevalent enough to bleed into a game that's a master piece in my humble opinion. 

If you're curious, like I was, or if you'd like a mini-dive into your own psychology (or just want to reflect on life for a bit) and not have it be uber intense. I think that this game is worth it.

Lindo es la primera palabra que viene a la mente al describir LoveChoice, el estilo artístico, la música y la escritura son fantásticos en esta trilogía de cuentos.

A primera vista, puede pensar que está limitado a las opciones motivadas que se muestran, pero, si miras más de cerca y juegas con el cursor, descubres que hay nuevos disponibles, hay dos o tres finales diferentes en cada historia

Las historias están muy bien escritas y son realistas, a veces puede ser doloroso con lo real que es, como notar fallas en su pareja o querer estar con ellas, pero el tiempo y la distancia le impiden acercarse, puede ser fácil elegir opciones egoístas ya que está controlando la narrativa, pero los resultados de esas elecciones reflejarán cómo su pareja piensa en usted.

En general, LoveChoice es una pequeña antología encantadora de la que me gustó absolutamente, tenía historias fuertes, mecánicas interesantes, bellas artes y música, y algunas verdades de la vida real sobre las relaciones, con un precio que vale la pena. Puedo decir que se puso mucho corazón y amor en este título.

A wonderful game that should cost way more then it does, while being very short compared to other games with you being able to 100% it in 3 hours what matters more is the message that it brings with it. it's about falling in love and the issues that come with it as well as how to solve them without any side taking the blame, as well as how sometimes it's better to let go of a relationship despite both of you being in love so that you both can pursue your dreams rather then settling for normal and neither one of you being happy when you can always be together in the future, as well as learning that the most important thing that we can have in a relationship, is trust. the game isn't so much a game about people falling in love but reflection of how complicated love can be.

131295611.review:
This is by far the best romance game I have ever played, one of the best game ever honestly. I played trying really hard to 100% the game and I loved every second of it. The game phenomenal in portraying falling in love and maintaining a healthy relationship, because of that the game was very relatable.

Playing the game at first I got the break-up ending, because I suck at reading into things and always take everything at face value. This game has made me realize how to be better at relationships. I did better on Love Distance as a result, but I still got the bad ending. The second playthrough I got a better ending, but it was still not the satisfactory outcome.

Now the last ending of Love Distance, the whole reason I wanted to right this review. The long distance aspect I relate to so much, spending the days talking to your partner, connecting through mutual interests and certain things we both love so much. The ending where you break-up so because of the distance and both of you needing to have your future was bittersweet to me. It's how me and my ex broke up. The part where you have to click the box multiple times and keeps moving around is so accurate to hard it is to say "I want to break up", especially when you both still love eachother and don't want to. It happened to me and those words were the hardest to say in my entire life, we both loved eachother so much. I was devastated for a while afterwards, I felt like an import piece of me was gone, and it would take a very long time to get back. It took a while, but I got over her being completely gone from my life.

This game makes me want to reach out to her, but there needs to be more time for us to grow individualy. We're not ready to talk to eachother yet, I will wait until we are ready. There are still things I want to apologize for saying right after we broke-up, as I was heartbroken and didn't reflect my actual feelings. We probably won't ever be together again, but I hope in the future we will once again be friends.

I love you Valy <3

131213230.review:
This may be the one time I feel like putting my own thoughts in a steam user review might actually be helpful, because I really enjoyed this game, but I was very nearly put off playing the rest of it after completing the first story, and glancing at some of the negative review tells me that a lot of the people leaving negative reviews thought similarly. I figured I'd leave a review that might help those people feel a bit less crazy, as well as explain what the rest of the game did to reel me in after the first story left me feeling unsatisfied.

My problems with the first story come down to both a lack of proper conveyance as to what you're actually able to do, as well as the solutions to the problems presented becoming predictable after this was realized. I went through it twice, trying different things both times, only to end up with the bad ending again with no signs that I did any better. It wasn't until I looked up a guide that I learned that you can interact with the environment. More frustratingly, one puzzle required me to scroll down on the mouse wheel in order to see certain important elements. The fact that this is even possible is not conveyed at all, and it never comes up again. Once I figured out I could do these things, finishing the first story with a good ending was just as simple as finding the spots I was supposed to click on the screen, which left me feeling like I got the best ending, not because I did a good job, but because the game screwed me about until I looked up a guide. That being said, it wasn't without it's good points. There were two puzzles in there that did feel thematically appropriate enough to serve the story's message. One of them I probably could've figured out on my own if I hadn't already gotten frustrated enough to look up a guide. Having completed the game, I get the message this story was trying to get across, but the way it was executed resulted in it falling kind of flat.

The second story comes along and either helps fix my problems with the previous story, or turns those problems into positives. This one starts by forcing you to interact with something in the environment in order to proceed, which would've helped convey that you can do that if it was present in the first story. That segment is followed up with a puzzle that was able to help me understand what was going through the head of the main character through game mechanics alone, and this isn't the only puzzle in this story to do that. Without wishing to spoil, the predictability that dragged down much of the first story ends up working to the benefit of the second story, through the ways they subverted my expectations. In the first story, it felt like my expectations were being subverted about what I could do, rather than what I should do. I never felt that way in story two.

The third story switches up the format by becoming a point-and-click, the puzzle design of which is pleasant enough, but what sucked me in about that particular chapter was how the game kind of tricks you into getting the bad ending, but unlike story one, shows you what you can do differently to achieve the best outcome. In this instance, it felt like it wanted me to see the difference the two choices made, and it presented the "here's another things you could've done" thing in believable way. I saw the consequences of the bad choice first, without feeling frustrated and like I was being railroaded into the conclusion they were going for.

Each of the three stories could be summed up with the phrase "subversion of expectations". The first story subverted my expectations in a way that made me feel like the way forward was hidden from me by simply not knowing what I could actually do in the game. However the other two stories subverted my expectations in a way that made me feel like I was naturally ending up in the scenarios the devs wanted me to end up in, rather than getting me stuck in the conclusion they wanted by being overly obscure, as well as getting me to feel and think the things that the main characters of those stories might be feeling and thinking. I wish I could go into greater detail, but I would end up spoiling my favorite parts of the game. If you end up picking this game up, and you end up as put off by the first story as I was, I'd suggest you give it a little more time. You might as well, you've got 2 hours before the refund window is up. Even then, that $2 price tag ain't gonna do much damage to your wallet.

131178357.review:
Love Choice is a short experience sharing the stories of three couples. The first two are more linear in the storytelling, while the third functions more as a point-and-click detective mode. None of the stories are long in of themselves - the shortest being the third - and probably won't take any longer than an hour and a half, give or take. How you are affected by the actual content of the stories will boil down subjectively from person to person, although I can certainly see how people could be moved by the stories, or at least the themes they personify. 

The first story is the most straight forward of the bunch, but also isn't. Without giving away mechanics or story beats, it encourages failure your first time going, resulting in a breakup in universe. Upon subsequent playthroughs is when you realize what you need to accomplish to succeed. It isn't clear at first how to solve these dilemmas at first, but once you solve one, you can pretty easily solve the others and get that perfect ending. The one exception is a dilemma with a solution requiring mechanics that aren't prompted at any time or even used at any other point in the future in either this story or the other three. Once you get past that though, the result feels heartwarming and worth the effort, great or small. 

Passing the first story successfully should make it easier to pass the second one. The mechanics required for success are indicated more clearly here as opposed to the first story's approach. The story won't even continue if you "fail" during dilemmas, and will even allow you to jump to specific chapters to pick up at any point. On a personal level, the story itself on this one was more relatable and compelling for me. Perhaps it's mainly because unlike the other two stories, the couple have their own names. I also like the story's approach to the endings, comprising of two (discounting the fail ending). Again without giving anything away, a damned if you do, damned if you don't scenario that is heartbreaking in concept. 

The third story is very simple. There isn't a fail state here at all and the pace of it falls onto the player. Just follow the clues and find the answers you seek. Once you get the ending normally, you can go back to the first chapter that instigated the sequence of events. From there, you do what you have to do and achieve the game's main ending and end credits. The song at the end is really nice btw. 

All in all, the game is small, affordable, and pleasant in it's presentation to it's simple storytelling. There's also some good wallpapers you can get by playing the game as well if you like the artstyle. It won't take you long to finish or even to complete either. Whether you purchase on sale or whole price, give this game a try. You may like what you see.

The horror!*

Her emotions from work apparently aren't pleased with your responses. And the response options are very, "authoritative." Like no one needs you to tell them how they feel or assume what happened. You listen, you nod, you agree... that's being a good listener. You don't say, "Well this probably happened" or "it's always this way." Were you there? You don't know. Shut up Wesley.

On a moonlit walk, I would not want someone to grab at my hand. Tell me about the moon, let's connect on something else first before you invade my personal bubble. I swear NSFW games understand how to woo a woman or anyone for that matter, better than this. Jus' sayin'

Sorry, not for me. I wish people would stop thinking so linear when it comes to stereotypes. There are cool females out there who look at you bizarrely when you cry and ask you what the heck is broken on your face BUT... they DID CRY when Wash died!

If you're not a gender typical human, you may want to pass on this game.

130245613.review:
I always thought that I would be a good boyfriend because of certain qualities. I was always confused that a girl didn't reciprocate the feelings I had for her and would always think: "now isn't the time I guess..."

Then I played the first story and got a bad ending. To be fair, I thought the choices that were given were what I needed to choose from but I still felt like what I did wasn't good enough. Then I clicked somewhere I shouldn't and got a different outcome. I thought outside of the box and didn't just immediately do what I thought was obvious. A wave of realisation came over me. How I went about relationships (platonic and romantic) always ended up in people being hurt. After that, I wanted to be better. I realised the flaws I had and how I could go about fixing them. I realised how I hurt people and how I should've handled a situation. 

How the fuck does a 2 dollar game cause this much self-introspection as well as revealing the errors of my ways? A 2 dollar game offering genuine advice of how to act better for both yourself and others? 

Buy this game, because for two dollars, you get a fun puzzle game, story, and most importantly, [i]priceless advice. [/i]

130171442.review:
The best things about LoveChoice is that it takes advantage of beign a video game and it definitely feels made with love. 

The three stories presented could easily be short writings you read on the internet, but the smart and simple ways in which it allows the players choice not only through dialogue but through gameplay make it a unique experience that immersed me more than any romance film ever could. 

I would recommend playing the stories in the order they are presented, as the first one is a nice introduction to the characteristics of the interaction aspect of the game and it has multiple endings that make it great for replays. The second story is about as bittersweet and heartbreaking as romance tales can get, and it was the one that got me the closest to crying, thankfully the third story is a comfy and heartwarming conclussion that serves as a pallette cleanser from the heavy emotions of the previous chapter.

Overall LoveChoice thrives from it´s simplicity and passion and it´s a small game that could have a big impact on you.

[h1]Una chulada; una experiencia corta pero intensa.[/h1]

Si te gustan las historias de amor, no puedo dejar de recomendarte este juego. Lo componen tres breves historias interactivas ricas en detalles y contenido que, como mínimo, te robaran una tímida sonrisa y que te harán verter alguna que otra lágrima. 

Cada una de estas se siente única y aborda diferentes escenarios que se pueden dar entre dos personas que se aman, y dependerá de ti el desenlace al que se llegue en estas. A veces, en lo que al amor respecta, somos capaces de hacer más de lo que pensamos que podemos hacer, y a veces, a la inversa.

La estética del juego con sus dibujos y coloreados sencillos es realmente cautivadora, y es que el apartado artístico acompañado de la música del juego, armonizan totalmente para atraparnos en un adorable mundo de contradictorios sentimientos lleno de decisiones difíciles.

En fin, el juegos es económico, original, sencillo y eficaz; si te gustan está clase de juegos, no tienes excusa alguna para no jugarlo.

125389301.review:
In LoveChoice, you get to experience 3 stories who cover various aspects of love. Young love, Distant love and a long time love that has been established.

The first story starts with a young couple that met at a Game Jam and bond over like interest, another story involves childhood friends develop a long-distance relationship. The last story covers a married couple who struggle to keep the spark in their relationship through the wife playing detective as her husband displays for her a scavenger hunt for their anniversary.

As someone who has played my fair share of visual novels, I quickly caught on to the choices and doing activities such as reading a Twitter feed to get information on another person to cater to them to get the best outcome. The little mini games and such that come with each story is something I found both cute and charming.

The game truly makes you work for the good endings as you have to interact with the backgrounds and clickables to find new routes that will ultimately lead to the best ending for each story if done right. 

I love it when visual novels are more than texts and characters on a screen.

Interactable scenes that change the story? Mini-games? I love it. 

A cute and charming game with a beautiful soundtrack that I would highly recommend if you're a soft-hearted person with a passion for love stories.

I don't think I've ever played a game that has as much heart in it as LoveChoice. The art, the music, the writing, and the lessons it teaches really make this game hit hard emotionally. 121690145.review:
Cute, Fun, Layered, Thoughtful and worth the money.

Pros: Stories that must be replayed to find the true ending, not difficult, just require a little thought. 
- 3 unique narratives that all find a way of hitting a different aspect of love that may resonate strongly with some viewers.
- simple puzzles
- charming music, ending music is excellent!
- unlockable pictures that provide a clue to how much of the story you have seen or if there is more to find
- Longer than expected, beatable in a day, but probably three or four hours of content depending on if you want to see all the branching paths

Cons:
- None

Still unsure? Watch my playthrough here to help make up your mind:

119972145.review:
This is someone's relationship advice as a game. Cute artstyle, but not worth your while if you already understand the concept of "treat them like a person" "let them explore who they are and who they want to be" and also the third lesson is straight-up "trust that your spouse isn't cheating on you" which isn't exactly helpful.

By the way, in that third lesson, the story gives you the option to ask your husband about the suspicious phone call that you saw (which is what makes you think they're cheating in the first place) but even if you choose to confront him, literally nothing about the story changes. I thought the whole point of the first story was to communicate well and try to understand how your partner feels! Not to just brush things off and simply *assume* that everything's fine between you two- especially so, when we later see in multiple examples around the house (such as not cleaning the litterbox and not helping with laundry) that your husband hasn't exactly been a great comfort, and appears to leave many chores for *you* to do instead. What happened to balance?

Also, while the gameplay *is* charmingly simple, it's actually quite difficult to *see* what you need to do. Light puzzle spoilers dead ahead: needless to say, the way objects are highlighted by the cursor hardly makes them stand out at ALL. I'm almost wondering if the developers decided to do this to extend the playtime. After all is said and done, it feels like half of my time with this game was spent randomly clicking the screen because barely anything in the backgrounds stands out enough to look like it should be clickable. And don't get me STARTED on how they made you use the scroll wheel that one, SINGULAR time. If it were a regular game mechanic, I could forgive it, but wow, you REALLY do just have to *guess* to solve that one.

And one more thing- one of the dialogue choices in the first story- that being: "can i hold your hand"- is a perfectly fine thing to ask, and I don't know why the game treats it as thought it "ruins the mood". Have you considered how important consent is? Even for seemingly simple things like that? You don't know what any given person has gone through in their lives. Physical touch isn't automatically welcome from an acquaintance just because you've had a nice night with them so far.

But hey, it was two bucks, right? Ya get what ya pay for.

119962163.review: This game was so beautiful, story 1 really got me emotionally. But all 3 was wonderful, and heartwarming. And it's not hard nor take long to complete it. Took me almost 2 hours. 2 hours of game-play for a game ill probably remember for years. <3

119621062.review: This is a great game. I didn't realize how cold and unfeeling I was until I played not even 2 minutes of this game, and as my digital girlfriend left me for being cold and calculative, I wondered what I did wrong. I was dumbfounded, I thought we were doing well, but apparently not. Needless to say, my first time playing it didn't go over well, and so I decided to give it another go. The second time I played it, I discovered these zodiac ciphers within the game's text, as I shook, dragged, rotated, and spammed my mouse across my screen to find solutions outside the choices presented to me. I eventually found that there lie something beneath the surface of every encounter, sometimes no words were needed for a perfect moment, and other times you realize just bending to another's will isn't right, and there must be an understanding among the two people to maintain a stable relationship. Although I failed spectacularly my first time playing LoveChoice, I realized that only made me appreciate the game on my second run even more. I looked closer at the text and no longer was it just cold text, it had meaning and emotion behind it. My failure helped me learn from my shortcomings, and I worked to better myself and unknowingly bettered myself too, if only by a little. Surprisingly, this candy bar priced game made me take a  look at my self, and gave me more enjoyment in the first 5 minutes than some A list games give in the first 2 hours. I never played a dating game before, but I recommend people who also haven't play this one. In conclusion, you should definitely play this game, I mean you spent a couple minutes reading this, so I'm sure you have a couple more, just ruffle though the couch cushion to find a bit of change and enjoy the game.

116329442.review: LoveChoice is a thoughtfully designed relaxing point and click detective puzzle solving short game which can be completed in 1 hour if you have already discovered the core mechanic of the game.  The love stories of this game resonance well with most ordinary couple's real world experience, but I mainly recommend this game to boys who are already in or had been in a relationship to get the most value out of it, but do not buy if you are the impatient type who will stop playing before you discover the core mechanic of the game.  There is really no choices made in the game that is wrong in my opinion, there are good options and some better options.  When problems arise in a relationship, it is always easy to attribute the problem to the other, and that's true in reality, and well portrayed by this game.  The mechanics of the game are not as simple as they seem, on some level you may even need to use the scroll wheel on your mouse, you may need to think out of the box to open a different plot.

I would say we always tend to ignore others' efforts and overrate ours. It's the same in the game or in the real life. If we look at it from the outside, a girl who 
can give me a forgiving hug just after she got cursed by me, who is willing to spend 3 years with me regrating what I did, who can share the same dream and purpose of life with me. I can't say she making no effort. Besides, we can know that they broke up at the BE of the story. But we don't know who brings that up. Still, we are tending to think that was her fault. It's a sad but realistic part of this story.
The 1st story act as a tutorial in the game. If you are more interested in complicated story-telling, maybe you should try the other stories. Forget about it if you already did.
Thank you for trying my game and leaving comments.
Best wishes

111255723.review:
There's something really charming about small passion projects. They don't tale a lot of your time, but they get their point across and you feel a strong connection to the developer and the message they are trying to get across. LoveChoice is an example of one of these games.

LoveChoice is a small Visual Novel game that breaks you into 3 different stories. The first story is how a man and woman meet at a Game Jam and they develop a relationship. Depending on your actions they will stay together or break up. The second story is about a boy named a Stan and a girl named Grace. They start as childhood friends and eventually become more, but their dreams and aspirations separate them into a long distance relationship. The final story is about a wife who is nervous that her husband is hiding something from her and decides to search the house to see what he is hiding.

One of my favorite things about LoveChoice is how it knows what players expect from a Visual Novel and turns it on its head. The first story, for example, will always lead to a bad ending if you play the game like a standard visual novel. However, at the end, it gives you hints on what you need to do to get the good ending. A lot of times it's not about making a choice, but looking for the third option *hint hint*. Because of that, it made the stories and the lessons so impactful and I really loved it.

The music was also very beautiful. Another thing I loved was the mini games and little effects they added as well. There would be scenes where your mouse cursor is pulled or repelled away from a certain thing on the screen and I really loved that effect as it really hit home how tough it was to make said choice or decision.
I have no gripes with this game honestly. It is short and to the point, and once I figured out what it was trying to teach me, it made me appreciate it greatly!

Final verdict? This is a wonderful game and will only take 1-2 hours of your time at most. The lessons and stories were really beautiful and I cherish the them greatly. Definitely check this one out if you're looking for a unique Visual Novel game with a nice premise. Thanks for reading!

106944369.review:
First of all thank you Ye for this beautiful game about love, and trying to spread the message of love.

Secondly I wanted to say that the song for the End Credits is beautiful.

And now for a brief review of the game or Visual Novel, or rather games or Visual Novels as this game comprises of 3 separate stories.  Each game within the main game is not that long, but put them altogether and to get all the endings and achievements it took me about 2 hours.  Each story tackles relationships from a different angle.  And each one tries to teach something about relationships and love.  The message itself is beautiful.  If you start from the first game, and then play the second one, and then the third you will find it surely but steadily snowballing emotionally.  Each story is unique, and beautifully told.  And I think it could also be educational for people who have not had many relationships.  But the core message itself is LOVE.

And honestly for the price I paid for it, it was definitely worth experiencing.  I personally could relate to each one of them.  And I found the stories to be beautifully told.  

So to sum it up:

-  This is a collection of 3 games.
-  They're all about LOVE
-  Each story is unique in it's own way, and well written.  They will most likely have an emotional impact on you.
-  The games employ interesting point and click mechanics

And last but not least, MAKE SURE you watch the END CREDITS in FULL or you will miss out. :)

I went through the game over three sittings (there are three separate stories to play through) and I was emotional almost the entire time..

The only exceptions were once I figured out "how to play" or what the game expected of me outside of dialogue choices and I was constantly feeling and clicking and dragging and scrolling around the screen to make sure i didn't miss anything... which I still usually had to go back a second or third time to find what I knew I was looking for! 

Solid storytelling. Concise dialog (in English at least.) The music is essentially the same through the stories but it hits just right every time. A lot of love went into this game. It's worth it.

105892222.review:
第一个游戏我真的很想吐槽，感觉想传递道理，但是人物性格和处理逻辑都有点奇怪。第二和第三个游戏情节很简单，感觉逻辑处理得更好。

开始玩的时候还想着看看从男生角度谈恋爱是什么感觉，然而前n遍玩第一个游戏的时候简直想直接给这个游戏一个大差评。都send的什么message，女生这么矫情，沟通几乎为0，语气看得出来不是很热情，但是联系到后面的信简直是passive aggressive。很多选项根本不想选，但是为了剧情继续发展必须选，结果还是designed to fail。
后面get了设计之后，感觉发展终于正常了一些，也明白游戏是想说“很多时候的最佳选项C，是需要自己去思考才能找到”。我依然觉得设计实在是非常难懂，算是有新意吧，但是这个不看剧透真的可能自己摸索出来吗？
故事的逻辑我勉强可以理解，但是这个感觉不是正常人谈恋爱的逻辑，更像是in hindsight总结出来的经验之谈。任何relationship都不是一次选择错了就直接完蛋，总是需要磨合和沟通的。而且全靠男生单方面去努力有毛线用，女生对不感兴趣的话题上就会“嗯...”，不会反馈也不会往其他话题上引，简直AI，丝毫看不出彼此都感兴趣（要是前面给了很多次机会都不行了，为什么还能发展到恋爱关系啊）。难道男生就只能是硬追的那什么吗，真的太可怜了。
（钢针你以为你听明白了这些道理，但其实你在没有经历过之前是不可能真正明白的。最后哪怕你从这个游戏的说教里懂了那些道理，希望你不会把这些道理千篇一律地应用到每段恋爱里。）
105892222.developer_response:
嗨，感谢你花时间玩我们的游戏，同时也抱歉游戏未能让你满意(-_-)

你也在评论中提到了游戏设计的相关概念，我也回答一下我的看法吧。如果觉得有可以参考的地方，可以看看，如果觉得没有，还请无视哈。

关于男女差别
首先，从创作者的角度来说，本作中所有角色其实都无关男女，改变某些用词，其实男女是完全可以互换过来的。只是我很难在一个相对现实的故事当中，采用无性别的角色进行创作。如果给了你性别差异的印象，很抱歉。同时，我也很想知道，是哪个地方会给你这种印象？作为一个以“弱角色”为主要写作方向的游戏，其实在大多数时候都淡化了很多角色身上的特点。就是希望把“事情”突出，而淡化“人”。这刚好是和大多avg和vn中的强角色写法背道而驰的。倒是比较像一些寓言故事中的写法，好像狼来了的故事中，小男孩说谎了，不代表故事的message是“男生爱说谎一样”，虽然这样的读解也不能算是错误的。再次，故事并非想表达男女之间的差异。但如果让你产生这样的误会，很抱歉。

关于游戏设计及引导
是游戏设计上，第一个故事的设计当然不算是容易理解的。但为了让玩家获得真正的eureka moment，设计上我只能提供软性引导。在一部分玩家觉得提示太明显，而另一部分玩家觉得提示太隐晦的时候。作为设计师，我会通过数据我检查设计是否达到了应该有的目的。目前steam的数据显示，有7成以上玩家获得了BE以外的结局。虽然通过玩家社区反馈，我的印象并非如此，但哪怕悲观点看，当中有一半玩家是通过攻略发现玩法的，也有大概3成半玩家可以自力通过。考虑到还有不少买了不玩的玩家，以及这是一个相对激进的，带有实验性的设计，这个数字我是比较满意的。而其实游戏设计的软性引导非常多，这里只能挑一些最优代表性的说明(如对更详细内容有兴趣，可以去看我B站的视频)：1、吵架、聊电话的选项，因为只有一个选项，所以其实如果玩家BE了一次，又有看到反馈的话，其实就知道正确答案不会是跟着选项走。2、只有两个选项的选项，特意设计给遍历选项的玩家。BE两次，有看反馈的话其实也应该明白了。虽然按照逻辑是这样，但如同玩家容易被游戏的固有思维影响一样，我们在恋爱中其实也容易被一些生活经验的固有思维影响。这时候，沟通往往不一定是有效的。

关于沟通、女主
在我说对女主的主观感受以前，我想先说两点不一定大家都能看到的客观事实：1、无论男主角怎样做，男女主角都会起码一起生活3年的时间。2、在分手线中，男女主角是因为什么原因分手，是谁提的分手，是没有交代的。我们只是知道在他们分手一段时间后，女主角给男主角寄了一封信，信里面，说了一些他们交往的时候，她很在意的事情。
从我的角度来说，一段持续3年的关系中，完全没有沟通我是不太相信的。而一个无论如何都会与男主角在一起起码3年的女孩，会在和男主角聊微信前特意发个朋友圈的女孩，会在吵得不可开交的时候，只要对方不骂人就给与拥抱的女孩，真的是很冷淡嘛？如果以常规avg女主的角度来看，我赞同她是不够热情的。但如果以一个普通人的角度来看，个人认为她这样的性格当然不是完美的，但完全可以理解。反过来说，如果她是因为信中提及的那些“小事”就大吵大闹，要和男主分手，那么不才是更容易被认为是矫情而不讲道理的嘛？
当然，玩家是用大概10分钟去体验一段3年关系中的片段，没有感受到也是可以理解的。但这10分钟当中其实也有不少的反馈和沟通，我想是大于大部分我们生活中的10分钟的。说到底，哪怕已经明确说出口的话，听者没法在理解之后想办法解决，最终也会成为无效沟通。至于把第一个故事的几次循环，看成是同一对男女间的多次尝试、沟通，还是经过几段关系后，男主最终明白，这就是读者的自由了。正如你说的，没有经历过，是不会明白的，对吧。
至于努力，无论游戏中还是现实中，我想我们都很难看到对方的努力。想想在分手线中，在女生的眼里，男生又做过什么呢？但女生依然一直陪在他身边，不是吗？
讽刺的是，在分手的时候，在爱不存在的时候，或许这些都一文不值。无论在游戏中，还是现实中。

再多的就不说了，一说游戏设计相关内容总是没完没了(/ω＼)
希望没有打扰到你。
祝你生活工作，事事顺利！

***UPDATE after playing the game a year later in order to achieve a perfect game:

Not gonna lie, I still don't like this game. I get what the devs are trying to do, but idk, it just isn't for me. But hey, cute graphics <3***

105527342.developer_response:
Hi, thank you for your time and comment, and sorry about your bad experience.
I am the main designer and programmer of the game, and I want to share a thought from a designer perspective. It's might not make your experience better, but maybe it will help you understand why the game designed like it is now.
In the first story, players experience a 3-year long relationship with around 10 mins. I don't believe there is zero communication in a 3-years relationship. And considering no matter what the boy actually did, the girl will live with him for at least 3 years long. I personally don't think she is picky. Besides, we actually don't know why they two broke up from the story, or who started the "broke up" conversation. What we know is that after their break up, the girl sends a letter to the boy and tell him about her feeling when they are still together. Is that really a terrible thing? Sadly, when the love is gone, we tend to consider it's our partner's fault, just like we did in a real relationship.
Telling players you can click things is way easier than designing all the "soft indications" in the game. I can do that, but it won't provide players the real eureka moments. I can't provide the eureka moments and make sure everyone can figure out the trick in the meantime. Still, sorry about your experience. Besides, there is actually many hints in the game, way more than we have in a real relationship I think, after all it's a game. Sadly, we tend to ignore them no matter there is a game or a real relationship.
I'm not good at English, I hope I make myself clear enough. 
Sorry again about you experience.
Besides, you can still try the rest of the game if you want. I think they can surpise you even after the first story. But if you are losing your interest, it's okay, hope you will find games you love.
Aiden Ye@AkabaStudio

105105302.review:
Lovechoice, es un videojuego dentro de la categoria de las novelas visuales. Una vez dentro del videojuego, nos encontraremos con 3 historias,Amor juego,Amor distancia y Amor detective, en los cuales tomando el papel del chico ,intentaremos conseguir nuestro final feliz de pareja.

El juego es corto,cada historia nos llevara como mucho 5 minutos....el tema esta, en buscar las  alternativas en su historias, para de esta forma conseguir sus diferentes finales,y todos los logros.

Aspectos positivos:Los 3 finales verdaderos(dificil eleccion,pero me quedaria con el de Amor juego),la musica del juego tocada a piano es genial.

Aspectos negativos:Es muy corto,sacar todo yendo muy,pero muy tranquilo,te llevara a lo mucho 2h.el minijuego que sale en la primera historia(Amor juego),a algunos les resultara incomodo y mas si quieres sacar su logro(aunque se puede repetir todas las veces que quieras).

Lovechoice me ha gustado...es cierto que es corto,pero merece ser probado y mas por el precio que tiene...Eso si, tienes muchas probabilidades,que la primera vez que juegues a su primera historia....Te lleves calabazas :D

104904378.review:
It's a good game, HOWEVER I think there are some flaws to point out and yes they are flaws.
The game is all about point and click, you have the dialogue box options which are always the wrong choice outside of one specific scenario. Instead of actually thinking on what the best option is you know you're doing the right thing so long as you don't click a dialogue option, and I think that's the opposite of what the game wants to accomplish. Sometimes it's just healthy to talk things out and not look for excuses to talk by looking at your surroundings. 

There's another specific puzzle where instead of using left click like you have the entire game you use scroll wheel. This never happens again. Why would you do this? How are you suppose to make a choice when you aren't even made aware of the option? Are you supposed to just spam every key on your keyboard and use every button on the mouse to try and figure out what does something? This puzzle is especially frustrating because it had the opportunity to fix the first flaw.

Now that's a lot of words but really this is a good game and those two paragraphs about two problems I had with the game, so two puzzles out what is over a dozen good ones. The game is genuinely good and I think there's a few lessons people can learn.

104535845.review:
[i] "8.5 out of 10 ♥ - totally did not see that one coming lol This might be one of a few times I don't mind having my feeling played" [/i]

Sometimes, we feel them inside but never say anything, and just let those feelings turn into small cracks that eventually cannot be mended. This game's title really said it all. It is all our choices to make.

[b] Story [/b]
When you thought that there is not much to the plot, and then that plot just suddenly hits you in the feel. There isn't any complicated story line or complex relationship between two people. Yet, every choice you made in the game really pulls out the realism of a relationship. 

[b] Graphic [/b]
The graphic is very simple that it almost looks like cute doodles on someone's diary, really fits the vibe of the game!

[b] Keyboard Control [/b]
Or rather clicking command in this case. Since you pretty use only your mouse to go through the game, most of the playthrough yields no problem with it, except for one stage where I had a rather tough time figuring out the right command needed.

[b] You will like this game if... [/b]
You are one of those who want to get their feeling played and those who like light-heart game with warm and fluffy feeling, or even a bit of heart broken. I personally got dumped on my first try lol but I shall persist and continue to go through all the routes to root for their love as well as the loves of all friends who share the experience through this game with me ♥

My opinion on the game:

A style of game in which you follow three romance stories with scenarios that will be different each time depending on your choice and actions. I am pleasantly surprised by the number of possibilities in each story, which generates some difficulty to finish the game completely! The OST, the drawings and the landscapes are very beautiful and simplistic, which brings a certain originality. Nevertheless, I'm a bit disappointed because of the length of the game which is not long at all, even very short, indeed I took barely 2h30 to finish it despite the difficulty. Anyway, I had a great time, this game is not expensive at all, so why deprive yourself!

102891205.review:
Giving this game a thumbs up because I want to support the developers. But don't get me wrong; there are quite a few things that feel a bit wrong here. It seems to be a trend in these interactive "shorts."

The first-time experience is designed for failure. I remember reading a review here that went something along the lines of "realise where you're going wrong and you'll understand why you were single for so long."

Sounded like a challenge – so I took it as one. I played the game twice, and "lost" both times. Then I read more reviews, of which one pointed out there's an "interactive" aspect to it that I may have overlooked.

I played the game the third time, and voila, that "helpful" review I read was indeed right. If I had done something like this, I would've "won" the game.

Now, here's the problem: How was I supposed to know that's how the interaction works? There's zero indication or hint to show it'd work that way. Hence, it's a design problem, not a player problem. The "think outside the box" strategy seems to overstretch quite a bit with visual novels and at this rate, it's frankly super tiring.

The game indeed does carry a heartwarming message. But the binary design direction feels like a cheap sucker punch each time.

Do you have a soft spot for love stories? Yes
Not interested in feelings and slow gameplay? You can skip this one.

91941688.review:
I was kinda disappointed at first. This game was not what I expected. I expected there to be choices, and for it to be like a "choose your own adventure" game with a love story. But I was wrong. It is more like a puzzle game. [spoiler]When you pick answers, they always end up with a "meh" outcome.[/spoiler] However, as I played more, I looked past that nonsense and realised how much heart and soul was put into this game. This game is so warm and fuzzy, and love that stuff.

This game was too adorable to rate it a thumbs down. And, mind you, I was being ridiculous because my amazing friend bought this game for me! So I have no idea what I was on. My mind randomly goes on crack sometimes.

The last story was my favourite in my opinion. The story was very well thought out.
The stories as also very realistic. The relationships are realistic, and the stories give great life advice! (Such as; Love works both ways. Relationships work only both make an effort to stay in contact, so on a so forth). But the romantic feeling never goes away! Literally real life true love stuff right here folks.

Since this game gave a feel of realism as well as a fuzzy romantic feeling, I believe this game will be very helpful to preteens. This information is very helpful in life.

Anyways, my checklist:

- In the English version, some words do not have spaces between them. Other than that the translations are spot on!
- In the last Love Choice Story, [spoiler]near the ending where you put the code in, and you get to the arrows, you can not exit out of it.[/spoiler]
